leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.22] r 42.22 Money paid into court (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Money paid into court (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 18)

p.text: If a party has paid money into court, the court may, in exercising its discretion as to costs, take into consideration both the fact and the amount of the payment.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.23] r 42.23 Costs in account (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 38)

leg:heading.title: Costs in account (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 38)

p.text: If the court orders that an account be taken and the account consists in part of costs, the court may, by the same or a later order, direct the registrar to refer those costs for assessment.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.24] r 42.24 Costs of solicitor appointed as tutor (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 41)

leg:heading.title: Costs of solicitor appointed as tutor (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 41)

p.text: If the court appoints a solicitor to be the tutor of a person under legal incapacity in connection with any proceedings, the court:
may order that the costs incurred by the solicitor in performance of the duties of tutor be paid:
by the parties to the proceedings or any of them, or
out of any fund in court in which the person under legal incapacity is interested, and
may make orders for the repayment or allowance of the costs as the case requires.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.25] r 42.25 Costs of trustee or mortgagee (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 42)

leg:heading.title: Costs of trustee or mortgagee (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 42)

p.text: Subject to subrule (2), a person who is or has been a party to any proceedings in the capacity of trustee or mortgagee is entitled to be paid his or her costs in the proceedings, in so far as they are not paid by any other person, out of the fund held by the trustee or out of the mortgaged property, as the case may be.
The court may order that the person’s costs not be so paid if:
the trustee or mortgagee has acted unreasonably, or
in the case of a trustee, the trustee has in substance acted for his or her own benefit rather than for the benefit of the fund.

In the absence of misconduct (such as, for example, an improper refusal of an offer to redeem: Squire v Pardoe (1891) 66 LT 243; 40 WR 100 ; Graham v Seal (1919) 88 LJ Ch 31) a mortgagee is ordinarily entitled to add to their security all costs, charges and expenses reasonably and properly incurred in ascertaining or defending their rights or in recovering the mortgage debt: Charles v Jones (1886) 33 Ch D 80 at 84 ; Re Leighton’s Conveyance [1937] Ch 149 at 152 ; Overton Investments Pty Ltd v Cuzeno RVM Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 27 at [61]; BC200300393 . Costs payable by a mortgagee are to be taxed on the ordinary basis that applies to costs ordered between parties: The Kestrel (1866) LR 1 A & E 78; Re Queen’s Hotel Co Cardiff Ltd [1900] 1 Ch 792 ; Re Adelphi Hotel (Brighton) Ltd [1953] 2 All ER 498 ; Central Mortgage and Housing Corp; Re Johnson (1971) 20 DLR (3d) 622 ; AGC (Advances) Ltd v West (1984) 5 NSWLR 301 ; although authorities can be found which support the proposition that a mortgagee is entitled to costs on a common fund basis: Ramsden v Langley (1705) 2 Vern 536; 23 ER 947 ; Cotterell v Stratton (1872) LR 8 Ch App 298; Re Griffıth Jones & Co (1883) 53 LJ Ch 303 ; National Provisional Bank of New Zealand v Games (1886) 31 Ch D 583; Re Leighton’s Conveyance [1937] Ch 149 . If the terms of the mortgage provide for the payment of costs on an indemnity basis, the court should normally exercise its cost discretion so as to correspond with the mortgagee’s contractual entitlement: Gomba Holdings (UK) Ltd v Minories Finance Ltd [1993] Ch 171 . A mortgagee’s entitilement to costs will depend on the reasonableness of the claim made by the mortgagees and any disentitling conduct of the mortgagee: Overton Investments Pty Ltd v Cuzeno RVM Pty Ltd, above, at [58]–[63].

This rule applies even though the mortgagor may have been granted legal aid under Legal Services Commission Act 1979 s 47 : Maher v Network Finance Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 503 and see Re Leighton’s Conveyance [1937] Ch 149 .

Ordinarily, a trustee who has acted honestly is entitled to an indemnity out of the trust fund in relation to expenses, including legal costs, incurred in connection with the administration of the trust: Miller v Cameron (1936) 54 CLR 572 at 578; [1936] ALR 301; (1936) 10 ALJR 35a; BC3600025 ; National Trustees Executors and Agency Co of Australasia Ltd v Barnes (1941) 64 CLR 268 at 274 and 277; [1941] VLR 133; [1941] ALR 58; BC4100006 Metropolitan Petar v Mitreski [2006] NSWSC 336; BC200602696 at [28]–[32] approved by the Court of Appeal in Petar v Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc [2006] NSWCA 277; BC200607955 at [27]; Cotterell v Stratton (1872) LR 8 Ch App 298; Re Knight’s Will (1884) 26 Ch D 82 ; Turner v Hancock (1882) 20 Ch D 303 ; Re Spurling’s Will Trusts; Philpot v Philpot [1966] 1 All ER 745; [1966] 1 WLR 920 ; Re Plant’s Estate; Wild v Plant [1925] P 139. The ordinary entitlement to indemnity is subject to some qualifications. It does not automatically apply to costs a trustee incurs in connection with matters primarily affecting the trustee’s personal interests: Nowell v Palmer (1993) 32 NSWLR 574 at 581–2 (unsuccessful executrix also sole beneficiary). Neither does it automatically apply to costs a trustee incurs in defending beneficiaries’ claims of impropriety: Frost v Boviard (2012) 203 FCR 95; [2012] FCAFC 60; BC201202489 .

Misconduct or serious neglect may result in loss of the indemnity entitlement: Re Beddoe; Downes v Cottam [1893] 1 Ch 547 at 562 ; Mead v Watson (2005) 23 ACLC 718; [2005] NSWCA 133; BC200502533 ; Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) v Mead (2004) 61 NSWLR 169; 185 FLR 76; [2004] NSWSC 731; BC200405114 (conducting proceedings with no prospect of material benefit to the liquidation); Thomas v Jones [1928] P 162; (1928) 139 LT 214; 44 TLR 467; [1928] All ER Rep 704 .

These two general principles necessarily require reconciliation where a trustee or executor unsuccessfully conducts proceedings that have little prospect of success, continues proceedings after failing to accept a reasonable settlement offer or unsuccessfully defends proceedings involving allegations about their own propriety or competence. In these situations unsuccessful trustees will not necessarily be deprived of their indemnity, but they are at risk unless their conduct can be characterised as reasonably proper administration of the trust estate: see National Trustees Executors and Agency Co of Australasia Ltd v Barnes (1941) 64 CLR 268; [1941] VLR 133; [1941] ALR 58; BC4100006 at 278–279 per Williams J; Fay v Moramba Services Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 725; BC201004657 at [4] ; Bovaird v Frost [2009] NSWSC 917; BC2000908101 at [26]–[45] . As a prudent practical consideration, therefore, trustees involved in contentious proceedings of these kinds should act promptly to seek judicial advice: Re Beddoe [1893] 1 Ch 547 ; Macedonian Orthodox Community Church St Petka Inc v His Eminence Petar The Diocesan Bishop of Macedonian Orthodox Diocese of Australia and New Zealand (2008) 237 CLR 66; 249 ALR 250; [2008] HCA 42; BC200807738 at [70] .

Where a trustee is an appellant it would be prudent to obtain a specific indemnity in relation to the costs of appeal since there is a conventional rule of long standing that a trustee who unsuccessfully appeals will be required to meet an order for costs personally: Re Earl of Radnor’s Will Trusts (1890) 45 Ch D 423; Re Walters (1890) 34 Sol Jo 564; Rosenthal v Rosenthal (1910) 11 CLR 87 at 99; 16 ALR 455 ; Perpetual Executors and Trustees Assn Australia Ltd v Wright (1916) 23 CLR 185 at 194, 198. However, there is clearly power to award the costs of an unsuccessful trustee appellant to be paid out of the trust fund in an appropriate case: Re Duncan [1934] VLR 355 at 362; Re Just [1938] St R Qd 93 at 96 ; Re Stuart; Johnson v Williams [1940] 4 All ER 80 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.26] r 42.26 Order confirming rule as to payment of costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 49; DCR Part 39A, rule 17; LCR Part 31A, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Order confirming rule as to payment of costs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 49; DCR Part 39A, rule 17; LCR Part 31A, rule 9)

p.text: If a party to proceedings in the court has become liable under these rules to pay any of the costs of the proceedings of any other party, the court may order the party so liable to pay those costs.
If:
a person is ordered by the court, by subpoena or otherwise, to attend court:
for the purpose of giving evidence, or
for the production of any document or thing, or
to answer a charge of contempt, or
for any other purpose, and
the person fails to attend in accordance with the order,
the court may order the person in default to pay any costs occasioned by the default.
If:
a corporation is ordered by the court, by subpoena or otherwise, to produce to the court any document or thing, and
the corporation fails to produce the document or thing in accordance with the order,
the court may order the corporation to pay any costs occasioned by the default.
This rule does not limit the power of the court to punish for contempt.

This rule expressly authorises costs orders against a person who fails to comply with a subpoena. It operates as an exception to the proposition that the court will not usually make an order for costs against a person who is not a party. But even apart from the present rule courts that have the power to issue a subpoena have an incidental power to make costs orders against a person in relation to non-compliance. Similarly the courts may order costs against a subpoena recipient who unsuccessfully challenges the subpoena or who unsuccessfully claims privilege in relation to matters sought in the subpoena: see Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 879; BC200606784 : see also [33.4.50] and [6.19.40] .
Legislation cited in [42.27.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.10.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1335, ss 596A–596B.

Orders may be made under the present rule against a person who fails to comply with orders, made under Supreme Court (Corporations Rules) r 11.10 , to attend an examination under Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) ss 596A–596B : Re Struthers (liquidator of PACI Pty Ltd) (No 3) (2005) 56 ACSR 238; [2005] NSWSC 1113; BC200510078 (Corporations Act 2001 s 1335 does not preclude costs orders against non-parties).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.28] r 42.28 Orders as to costs in relation to instalment order (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2(7A); LCR Part 27, rule 2(11))

leg:heading.title: Orders as to costs in relation to instalment order (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2(7A); LCR Part 27, rule 2(11))

p.text: If the court is of the opinion that a party has acted unreasonably in respect of the application for an instalment order, or for the variation or recission of an instalment order, the court may order the party to pay the other party's costs in relation to the application, or such part of those costs as the court thinks fit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.29] r 42.29 Patents, trade marks and designs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 28)

leg:heading.title: Patents, trade marks and designs (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 28)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court.
If:
an action or counter-claim for infringement of a patent, of a registered trade mark, or of the monopoly in a registered design, or
an application or counter-claim for revocation of a patent, or
an application for cancellation of the registration of a design or counter-claim for the rectification of the Register of Designs,

proceeds to hearing, costs are not to be allowed to the parties delivering any particulars of breaches, or of objections in respect of any questions raised in those particulars and relating to that patent, trade mark or design, except in so far as those questions or particulars are certified by the Supreme Court to have been proved or to have been reasonable and proper.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.30] r 42.30 Property (Relationships) Act 1984 (cf SCR Part 52A, rules 34 and 35)

leg:heading.title: Property (Relationships) Act 1984 (cf SCR Part 52A, rules 34 and 35)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court or the District Court in which the plaintiff commences proceedings for an order or relief under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 and the court:

adjusts one or more interests in property or makes an order for maintenance where the total value of all adjustments made, or of the order for maintenance, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court sitting in its General Division (as that limit was when the proceedings were commenced), or

declares a right in relation to property concerning which there was a bona fide dispute where the value of the extent of the right that was in dispute did not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court sitting in its General Division (as that limit was when the proceedings were commenced).
[subr (1) subst Amendment 48 of 2011 r 3, effective 9 September 2011]
Unless the court orders otherwise, the plaintiff is not entitled to payment of his or her costs of the proceedings.
On the application of any person, the court may order that this rule does not apply in respect of any proceedings, including proceedings yet to be commenced.
If an order is made under subrule (3) in respect of proceedings to be commenced, the originating process by which the proceedings are later commenced must bear a note of the order made.

level.toc-caption: [42.30.5] Costs in proceedings under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 — general principles

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.30.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Property (Relationships) Act 1984 s 20, s 27.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.1.

heading.title: Costs in proceedings under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 — general principles

p.text: The exercise of the discretionary powers conferred by s 20 (adjustment of property) and s 27 (maintenance) of the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 may be influenced by a number of considerations. The diversity of those considerations, which do not typically affect ordinary money claims, gives rise to the possibility of different views about what constitutes the relevant “event” for the purpose of exercising the costs discretion: see: Kardos v Sarbutt (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 206; BC200605726 at [26]–[35] ; Baker v Towle (2008) 39 Fam LR 323; [2008] NSWCA 73; BC200802889 at [10], [20]–[22], [83] . Nevertheless, if the substantive order made in the proceedings exceeds the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court, then the “follow the event” rule in UCPR r 42.1 provides a basic starting point and requires the court to identify the substantively successful party in the proceedings: Baker v Towle (2008) 39 Fam LR 323; [2008] NSWCA 73; BC200802889 at [22]–[24], [82]–[84] ; Dunstan v Rickwood (No 2) (2007) 38 Fam LR 491; [2007] NSWCA 266; BC200708317 ; Hayes v Marquis [2008] NSWCA 10; BC200800783 at [14], [82], [145] ; Jensen v Ray [2011] NSWCA 247; BC201106672 ; Separovich v Ferrao (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 346; BC201108759 . This will require more than merely identifying the issues that have arisen on the pleadings: Baker v Towle (2008) 39 Fam LR 323; [2008] NSWCA 73; BC200802889 at [23] and [84] ; Vollmer v Davidson [2006] NSWCA 79; BC200602235 at [21] (artificial to resolve liability for costs by reference to the formal status of the parties when neither has made a realistic offer).
The exercise of the costs discretion in these kinds of proceedings may also be influenced by:
the manner in which the parties have conducted the proceedings and in particular whether either party one has been disproportionately responsible for the incurring of costs;

whether any party has “bettered” a realistic offer of compromise: Vollmer v Davidson [2006] NSWCA 79; BC200602235 ; Kardos v Sarbutt (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 206; BC200605726 at [26]–[35] ; or has achieved “substantial” success in the proceedings: Chanter v Catts (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 179; BC200605062 at [6] ;

whether the order ultimately made would have been within the jurisdiction of the Local Court — in which case a successful plaintiff is not entitled to their costs unless the court otherwise orders. Chanter v Catts (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 179; BC200605062 ;

the justification for commencing proceedings in the Supreme Court, notwithstanding the value of the order ultimately made: Deves v Porter [2003] NSWSC 878; BC200305677 (claim based on constructive trust and also required an extension of time);

the value of the order actually made: Baker v Towle (2008) 39 Fam LR 323; [2008] NSWCA 73; BC200802889 (costs proportion reflected property adjustments made); Deves v Porter [2003] NSWSC 878; BC200305677 (desirable “rule of thumb” to cap costs so as not to exceed the value of the award); Johnston v McCallum [2005] NSWSC 17; BC200500387 (plaintiff obtaining $51,000 order — absence of reasonable offer from defendant — complex building and valuation evidence — costs capped at $100,000); Magera v MacIntosh (No 2) (2005) DFC ¶95-319 (no costs order — Plaintiff awarded $20,000 — Defendant denied relationship, but offered $50,000 plus costs); Jensen v Ray [2011] NSWCA 247; BC201106672 (costs capped to avoid disproportionate effect on the property adjustments made).
Legislation cited in [42.30.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 29.
The jurisdictional limit of the Local Court sitting in its General Division is to be found in the definition of “jurisdictional limit” in LCA 2007 s 29 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.31] r 42.31 Recovery of assessed costs in Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 46)

leg:heading.title: Recovery of assessed costs in Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 46)

p.text: A person is not entitled to his or her costs of proceedings in the Supreme Court (including costs of execution) to recover payment of costs included in a cost assessor’s certificate unless:
at the time of filing the certificate the amount of unpaid costs included in the certificate exceeds $150,000, or
it appearing to the Court that the person had sufficient reason for filing the certificate in the Court, the Court orders otherwise.
A party may apply for an order under subrule (1) without serving notice of motion.

If the applicant for an order under subrule (1) adds to the motion a request that the application be granted in accordance with this subrule, the Supreme Court may make the order in the absence of the public and without any attendance by or on behalf of the applicant.
A person is not entitled to his or her costs of filing a cost assessor’s certificate in the Supreme Court.
See also rule 36.10 in relation to the filing of cost assessors’ certificates.
In this rule, a reference to a certificate includes a number of certificates filed together under rule 36.10(1) and (2) .
[subr (5) insrt Amendment 43 of 2011 r 3 , effective 15 April 2011]
At any stage of proceedings, the court may order a party’s legal representative to serve on the party:
a notice that specifies:
an estimate of the largest amount (inclusive of costs) for which judgment is likely to be given if the party is successful, and
an estimate of the largest amount (by way of costs) that the party may be ordered to pay if the party is unsuccessful, or
a notice that specifies:
an estimate of the best outcome that the party is likely to achieve if the party is successful, and
an estimate of the worst outcome that the party is likely to undergo if the party is unsuccessful.
[r 42.32 insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[51], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.33] r 42.33 Certain costs orders not to be made unless parties have attempted to agree on amount

leg:heading.title: Certain costs orders not to be made unless parties have attempted to agree on amount

p.text: Unless the court otherwise orders, an order as to costs is not to be made under rule 21.13, 33.11 or 34.3 if the court is not satisfied that the parties concerned have attempted, but failed, to agree on the amount of costs to be paid in relation to the matter for which such an order may be made under that rule.
[r 42.33 insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 6 July 2007]
Legislation cited in [42.33.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 21.13, r 33.11, 34.3.

Parties are required to attempt to agree on the amount of costs and expenses that are payable for complying with a notice to produce ( rr 21.13 , 34.3 ) or a subpoena ( r 33.11 ) before seeking an order as to payment of those costs and expenses.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.34] r 42.34 Costs order not to be made in proceedings in Supreme Court unless Court satisfied proceedings in appropriate court

leg:heading.title: Costs order not to be made in proceedings in Supreme Court unless Court satisfied proceedings in appropriate court

p.text: This rule applies if:

in proceedings in the Supreme Court, other than defamation proceedings, a plaintiff has obtained a judgment against the defendant or, if more than one defendant, against all the defendants, in an amount of less than $500,000, and
the plaintiff would, apart from this rule, be entitled to an order for costs against the defendant or defendants.

An order for costs may be made, but will not ordinarily be made, unless the Supreme Court is satisfied the commencement and continuation of the proceedings in the Supreme Court, rather than the District Court, was warranted.
[r 42.34 insrt Amendment 36 of 2010 Sch 1, effective 10 September 2010]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.35] r 42.35 Costs order not to be made in proceedings in District Court unless Court satisfied proceedings in appropriate court

leg:heading.title: Costs order not to be made in proceedings in District Court unless Court satisfied proceedings in appropriate court

p.text: This rule applies if:
in proceedings in the District Court, a plaintiff has obtained a judgment against the defendant or, if more than one defendant, against all the defendants, in an amount of less than $40,000, and
the plaintiff would, apart from this rule, be entitled to an order for costs against the defendant or defendants.

An order for costs may be made, but will not ordinarily be made, unless the District Court is satisfied the commencement and continuation of the proceedings in the District Court, rather than the Local Court, was warranted.
[r 42.35 insrt Amendment 36 of 2010 Sch 1, effective 10 September 2010]
